full_text:
Configuring CostData Objects

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe the CostData Gosu classes to be
used by the rating engine to flexibly build up
the cost entities

¢ Define a new CostData class

CostData objects

| CostData objects G
Creates, a Merged and prorated, P ted
builds ore copied to Costs ersiste

Rating engine CostData objects Cost entities Database

¢ CostData objects are POGOs that mirror every cost entity
¢ They allow the rating engine to flexibly build up cost entities during rating

¢ Atthe end, the CostData objects are merged, prorated and copied to actual cost
entities to be maintained.

| General properties and methods Gi

¢ The CostData base class provides common financial fields which match the cost

delegate , such as standard, override, actual values for base and adjusted rate,
term amount, and prorated amount

¢ It also provides common methods used by the rating engine, such as:
* mergelfCostEqual()

* copyStandardColumnsToActualColumns()
* setRounding()

| Define a new CostData class

Gi

¢ For every cost subtype entity, create a CostData subclass

¢ CostData subclass name = CostEntityName + “Data” | eti |

« Example: PACostData, PersonalAutoCovCostData,

PersonalVehicleCovCostData
¢ Extend the abstract class CostData or its child classes for the line
« Add member variables to match columns on the cost entity

Add constructors
¢ Implement abstract properties and methods

* KeyValues()
* setSpecificFieldsOnCost()
* getVersionedCosts()

| Keys Gi

¢ CostData subclasses must define member variables to match the columns on their
corresponding cost entities
¢ Define a property that links to an entity instance such as key in a CostData class
* Key links one object to another

* Set the key field with the Fixedid property of the entity instance

* new PersonalAutoCovCostData ( start, end, cov.Currency, RateCache, vehicle.Fixedid, cov.Fixedid )
in PARatingEngine

PersonalAutoCovCost _|A taxable unit of price f..
implementsEntity Cost class PersonalautocovcostData extends PACostData<PersonalAutoCovcost> (
implementsinterfac gw.api.domain financial... gw.lob.pafinancials PA...
foreignkey PersonalAutoCov PersonalAutoCoy a> var _covID :

foreignkey PersonalVehicle PersonalVehicle

| Constructors Gi

¢ Date-based constructor: 1
« Used to create new CostData for a cost bearing object on the policy graph
« Parameters added to set the member variables specific to the subclass
* Cost-based constructor: 4
« Used to create CostData based on existing cost
* Constructors to support backward compatibility for non-multicurrency: 2, 3

abstract class PACostData<k extends PACost> extends CostData<R, PersonalAutoLine> {
construct (effDate : Date, expDate : Date, c : Currency, rateCache : PolicyPeriodFxXRateCache) {
super(effDate, expDate, c, rateCache)

»

2) construct cersoate : Date, expDate : Date) { super(effDate, expDate) }

GB) constrast : R) { super(c) }

( Q)) construct (< : Ry rateCache : PolicyPeriodFxRateCache) { super(c, rateCache) }

| Merging CostData objects G

The rating engine merges CostData objects with similar costs

J KeyValues() G

CostData subclasses must implement the KeyValues() property
Used to determine if two CostData objects are “the same”

Important when merging CostData objects (e.g. when there are multiple slices in a
branch)

Provides a list of values that collectively identifies the CostData object

PersonalAutoCovCostData.gs

protected override property get KeyValues() : List<Object> {
return {_vehicleID, _covID}

}

| setSpecificFieldsOnCost() G

* CostData subclasses must implement the setSpecificFieldsOnCost() method

« Used to create new cost entities or update existing cost entities based on
CostData objects

* CostData base class sets the general properties for the cost entity, such as
amounts and rates

¢ Subclasses must set the fields specific to the associated cost entities
¢ Non-FK properties: set properties directly on the cost entities

« FK properties: set properties using setFieldValue( costPropertyNames, Key )

costPropertyName: String specifying property name on av cost entity

Key: Key containing the fixedID for the object to be linked. Example:
cost.setFieldValue (“PersonalAutoCov”, _covID) in
PersonalAutoCovCostData.as

| Cost VersionList Gi

A Cost VersionList used by a rating engine is a set of cost rows for the same thing

| getVersionedCosts() Gi

* CostData subclasses must implement the getVersionedCosts() method
« Used to match corresponding costs to the CostData object
¢ Retrieve version lists of cost objects from the PolicyPeriod

¢ Repeat all costs for the target object and determine which cost entity instances
correspond to the current CostData object

¢ Use the Key field to match the cost if the CostData subclass has one

| Demonstration G

Configuring CostData objects

click here

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

Question

,~ — What are CostData objects? How are they named?

¢
4
¢

SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

Answer Gi

,~ — What are CostData objects? How are they named?
¢
or CostData objects are Gosu objects that mirror every cost on a policy graph. Each
CostData subclass has the same name as the cost entity followed by the suffix “Data”.

SSS eee oe eo ooo e SoD

Question

ae Describe briefly the two CostData constructors.
4
¢

SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

Answer

_~ — Describe briefly the two CostData constructors.
¢
7 The two CostData constructors are:
- Date-based constructor is created based on effective and expiration dates,
usually for a new cost object.

+ Cost-based constructor is created based on a pre-existing cost object that is
passed-in as a parameter.

SSS eee oe eo ooo e SoD

Question

ae Why are KeyValues needed?
4
¢

SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

Answer

,~ — Why are KeyValues needed?
¢
or KeyValues are needed to determine if two CostData objects are the same. The
KeyValues property creates a list of the Key Values. The rating engine uses it as it
merges CostData objects.

SSS eee oe eo ooo e SoD

Question G

,~ — Why can you not set properties directly on cost entities for both FKs?

¢
4
¢

SS oe ooo e eo oe ooooOoD

Answer Gi

ae Why can you not set properties directly on cost entities for both FKs?
or For non-FK properties, you can set the properties directly on the cost entity instance.
For FK properties, this approach does not work, because CostData objects store the
entity's fixed ID encapsulated in a key object. So the methods
setSpecificFieldsOnCost and setFieldValue provided by the CostData class must be
used to set the foreign key properties.

SSS eee oe eo ooo e SoD
